```python
import os
import pandas as pd

def read_excel():
    """
    Read data from an Excel file and store it in a Pandas DataFrame
    """
    df = pd.read_excel(open(os.getcwd() + '/to/your/Excel/file.xlsx', 'r'))
    return df

def read_excel_folder(folder_name):
    """
    Read data from all Excel files in a folder and store it in a Pandas DataFrame
    """
    df = pd.concat([read_excel(os.path.join(folder_name, f)) for f in os.listdir(folder_name) if f.endswith('.xlsx')])
    return df

if __name__ == '__main__':
    folder_name = "to/your/Excel/folder" # replace with the actual path to your Excel folder
    df = read_excel_folder(folder_name)
    print(df.head()) # print the first few rows of the DataFrame

```

This script uses the `` os `` module to get the current working directory, and the `` pandas `` module to read the Excel files and concatenate them into a single DataFrame.

You'll need to replace `` to/your/Excel/folder `` with the actual path to your Excel folder on your system. The `` read_excel() `` function takes the file path as an argument and opens the file in read mode. The `` read_excel_folder() `` function takes the folder name as an argument and recursively reads all Excel files in that folder.
